definition: to run/to run away/to escape/to run around (on errands etc)/(of a gas or liquid) to leak or evaporate/(verb complement) away/off

sentences.english: Well, maybe I could run errands or something.
sentences.chinese: 哦，或许我能跑跑腿儿什么的。

sentences.english: A horse takes them on errands, and a kitchen garden helps keep them well fed.
sentences.chinese: 马帮他们跑腿，厨房菜园使他们健康而营养充足。

sentences.english: He asked someone else to do all the legwork of gathering information.
sentences.chinese: 他叫了别人来做所有搜集资料的跑腿活。

sentences.english: Mary bullies her little brother into running errands for her.
sentences.chinese: 玛丽仗势支使她的弟弟替她跑腿。

sentences.english: What I do is a kind of legwork.

sentences.chinese: 社会媒体为中心，跑腿分享网站。

sentences.english: Will you putter around the house or spend the day on the go running errands orgrocery shopping.
sentences.chinese: 是在家里闲逛呢，还是去杂货店跑腿采购。

sentences.english: At the age of14, tom started working, running errands for a country club.
sentences.chinese: 汤姆14岁便开始工作，为一家乡村俱乐部跑腿。

sentences.english: "Doing chores and running errands could be part of that, " he said.
sentences.chinese: 做家务，跑腿办事可能是其中一部分。

sentences.english: He works as a gofer in a small store.
sentences.chinese: 他在一家小商店当跑腿。

sentences.english: Do errands or chores for them.
sentences.chinese: 为他们做家务或者跑腿。

sentences.english: Maybe I could run some errands for you or something.
sentences.chinese: 也许我能帮你跑跑腿什么的。

sentences.english: The boy found himself fagging for a black prefect.
sentences.chinese: 这个男孩发现自己总是为黑人跑腿打杂。

sentences.english: I have a lot of errands to run this morning for my boss.
sentences.chinese: 今天早上老板交给我好多跑腿的事。

sentences.english: He often runs errands for his neighbours.

definition: to do odd jobs/to do unskilled work
to order (sb) around/to send on an errand/to order away
to run this way and that (idiom); to rush about busily/to bustle about
to do sth in place of sb else
to send/to assign/to appoint/servants of an official/official messenger
official post/billet/commission/CL:件[jian4]/see also 差事[chai1 shi5]
to order sb about/to use sb
to follow everywhere/to always be there for sb at their beck and call
to act in a supporting role/fig. to play second fiddle
